citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility had a male wallaby that was previously diagnosed with lumpy jaw in January 2022. On January 16th, 2023,
the wallaby was found in respiratory distress, and died. Necropsy results revealed the animal suffered from whole body
emaciation, chronic inflammation of the GI tract, chronic inflammation of the mandible with proliferation. Additionally,
bacteria were found microscopically within the mandible and liver indicating there may have been an underlying
septicemia. After speaking with veterinarians involved with the case, it was determined that they had not been contacted
regarding the wallaby’s condition since October 2022. The licensee failed to identify the wallaby’s deteriorating body
condition. Failure to appropriately conduct daily observations and assess animal health can lead to unnecessary pain,
suffering, or even death. The licensee is responsible for conducting daily observations of all animals to assess their health
and well-being and provide a mechanism of direct and frequent communication so that timely and accurate information on
problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. The licensee must ensure
thorough daily observations are conducted and adequately assess animal health.

The primary enclosure for the two coyotes has standing water on top of the ice and frozen ground inside the enclosure.
The coyotes do not have access to water or shelter without walking through cold water that is sitting on top of ice and
frozen ground. Approximately 50% of the primary enclosure has standing water on top of ice and frozen ground. Without
access to dry shelter or being wetted by standing water, animals may not be able to maintain a healthy body temperature
which may result in discomfort or disease. A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water from
primary enclosures.

A male cavy that had been moved into an enclosure with a female cavy and her three baby cavies the morning of
inspection, was noted to have one wound that measured about 1" in diameter, and approximately 3-4 other wounds that
measured about 1/4" on its rear end. These wounds appeared to be dry, and scabbed over with hair loss. The licensee
stated that these wounds were bite wounds. The licensee further stated that they had noticed this cavy being picked on
by the other cavy in its original enclosure. This cavy was not moved to the enclosure with the female with three babies
until the bite wounds were noticed by the licensee. Incompatibility between animals may result in stress or fighting which
can lead to animal injury. Animals housed in the same primary enclosure must be compatible and affected animals must
be promptly removed if any incompatibility is present.
Corrected at time of inspection
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
JUSTINE O MALLEY, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Critical Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility had a male wallaby that was previously diagnosed with lumpy jaw in January 2022. On January 16th, 2023, 
the wallaby was found in respiratory distress, and died. Necropsy results revealed the animal suffered from whole body 
emaciation, chronic inflammation of the GI tract, chronic inflammation of the mandible with proliferation. Additionally, 
bacteria were found microscopically within the mandible and liver indicating there may have been an underlying 
septicemia. After speaking with veterinarians involved with the case, it was determined that they had not been contacted 
regarding the wallaby’s condition since October 2022. The licensee failed to identify the wallaby’s deteriorating body 
condition. Failure to appropriately conduct daily observations and assess animal health can lead to unnecessary pain, 
suffering, or even death. The licensee is responsible for conducting daily observations of all animals to assess their health 
and well-being and provide a mechanism of direct and frequent communication so that timely and accurate information on 
problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. The licensee must ensure 
thorough daily observations are conducted and adequately assess animal health. 
3.127(c)  Direct Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The primary enclosure for the two coyotes has standing water on top of the ice and frozen ground inside the enclosure.  
The coyotes do not have access to water or shelter without walking through cold water that is sitting on top of ice and

frozen ground.  Approximately 50% of the primary enclosure has standing water on top of ice and frozen ground.  Without 
access to dry shelter or being wetted by standing water, animals may not be able to maintain a healthy body temperature 
which may result in discomfort or disease. A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water from 
primary enclosures. 
3.133  Critical
   
Separation. 
A male cavy that had been moved into an enclosure with a female cavy and her three baby cavies the morning of 
inspection, was noted to have one wound that measured about 1" in diameter, and approximately 3-4 other wounds that 
measured about 1/4" on its rear end.  These wounds appeared to be dry, and scabbed over with hair loss.  The licensee 
stated that these wounds were bite wounds.  The licensee further stated that they had noticed this cavy being picked on 
by the other cavy in its original enclosure.  This cavy was not moved to the enclosure with the female with three babies 
until the bite wounds were noticed by the licensee. Incompatibility between animals may result in stress or fighting which 
can lead to animal injury. Animals housed in the same primary enclosure must be compatible and affected animals must 
be promptly removed if any incompatibility is present. 
Corrected at time of inspection 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
JUSTINE O MALLEY, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
